University of Saskatchewan,

Saskatoon.

May 15th.

I regret that I have not kept written records of such dates as you are interested in pertaining to the province of Saskatchewan. If my husband were with me, he could supply the information requested in connection with school, church, and United Grain Growers as he was the first secretary of your "Bennett" school district, 5 miles south of Gruin, and helped financially and otherwise in carrying on the Baptist church which was the first church organized in Gruin, and who was active in the United Grain Growers society from the first, as long ago as 1900.

But Mr. Wesley N. Brissett, my husband, passed away in January, 1950, and I cannot depend on my memory for dates except a few of the most personal ones.

I do not consider that these dates would be of interest to you. Of course, I remember many things but cannot give the dates of their happening. I have written to friends who may be able to supply certain dates, and I will return the archives as soon as receive replies.

Hoping the information may be of your assistance.

Yours sincerely,

(Mrs) Mary E. Brissett.
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. Mary E Birckett
Present Address: 45 San Jose Ave., Victoria B.C.
Pioneer Address: Girvin
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 2 in walking distance / mile & 1/2 miles

How many of these were bachelor's homes? neither

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? seldom

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? other days

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? mostly by invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? in afternoon and early evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? sometimes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) It was taken for granted that they would stop, no special form was used.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Our house was 1 mile from the road so visitors didn't often "drop in."

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family went. Usually there was a third man left at home.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Our house was too small for quilting parties. Auction sales were a sort of bee and got together later on.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. We lived in a 2-car-roofed shack at first but had a lumber frame house put up before winter. My husband did most of the work on the house but let several men from the village (joining) to shingle it in one day. The women were too busy at home to come.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Dances were the commonest form of parties when there was a house large enough. Some who didn't want a dance played cards. The women of our district liked to surprise one of us on our birthday. They were surprise parties each bringing a gift and lunch always in the afternoon and not continued after most had been visited.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. On one birthday.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, monthly, every once a month, etc.? No.

Some who didn't know a dance played cards. The women of our district liked to surprise one of us on our birthday. NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first ten years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes? Neither.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Often.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Other days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly by invitation.

5. What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In afternoon and early evening.

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Sometimes.

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take refreshment" used, or was some other expression common?) If so, what?

8. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Our house was a mile from the road and we rarely didn't offer refreshment.

9. Did the whole family go? Or did someone stay home to cook after the guests left?

10. Did you ever have "open house" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities? Tell me what this meant to you, and how often they occurred. We didn't do this very often.

11. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in town? Describe them.

12. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going to town every two weeks, month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Box socials were held twice or three times.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? Later than 1914 I think.

What material was it made of? Lumber

How large was it? 15' x 20'

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community through special funds.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) Both were used. The hall was used for larger gatherings concerning more people than in the school district.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Seldom as our two daughters were too young for dancing gatherings.

How were babies and small children provided for? Some were laid in cribs etc. when at the school, to sleep, and put to bed on the bed in homes.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? The school had a barn, for small animals.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist, We didn't play cards so we are not well informed on the matter.

Was there card playing for a prize? Not in the earlier years. There was a "five clubs" in the village in later years, with prizes each night.

What dances were popular? Square dances, waltzes, two-steps.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Card playing was used more by Anglican people than by U.C. people. If one distanced from that form of entertainment they stayed away. If invited to a home they might have chosen other games.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, parties, etc.) If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it? How many people attended?

10. What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? practically none.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? occasionally

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Sometimes attended one. They were usually attended or arranged by a few young men. Sometimes house parties were given for newly married couples attended by men and women, held in the village hall.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life become noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The (United) Grain Growers

Give the date and reason for it being organized. About 1910. To secure better facilities for farmers in handling their grain, including platforms, elevators, a fair system of supplying cars, shipping grain, etc.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. About 1916. A few farmers got together and appointed officers and held meetings in helpful spots, as Mr. Green and Mr. Bartlestone. Contributions soon followed.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? I judge 60% to 70%

How many women belonged? a few How often did it meet? fortnightly

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? Having elected Grain Growers from other towns occasionally, having debates and musical programs when possible, and picnics in summer, sometimes with an outside speaker.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? yes

When was it organized? 1917 or 1918?

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 20 or 30

Describe what you remember of its activities and services. I belonged to the women's section of Grain Growers and had not time for both. They usually sent me a list of their members & conventions at the University once a year. Homemakers included town and county members.

(There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? **Dances, socials in private homes, occasionally.**

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? **The grain growers met in halls in towns or villages and sometimes in country schools. The women's organization, also, met at several different times and places.**

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? **Not in the early years.**

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? **Yes. Give dates if possible.**

Who provided the lantern and the slides? **A visitor from some outside place or an implement company.**

What were the slides about? **Some were missionary slides with some strange unusual objects or scenes.**

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? **Kite flying was rarely seen.**

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? **Ball was almost as popular with girls as with boys. Perhaps skirts were in the way of girls playing marbles. In those days a girl would probably have strongly objected to wearing overalls.**

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable. They are fewer and not so generally attended.

READING

GIRVIN was a smaller village between 2 larger villages where grew towns.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

we took 3 or 4 books with us from Ont., some fiction, Dickens, a few history as Carlyles French Revolution, a few poetry Longfellow & Burns and literature as the works of E. Stanley Jones History of Canada, and England and of course, Bibles, Hugh Miller's biography, Lambs Tales from Shakespeare etc.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many? Very few books were also in wardrobes.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? We loaned our two.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not in the earlier days.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Seldom if ever.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Possibly. I have read the Canadian Geography.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

The Montreal Witness, The World Wide.
The Christian Guardian.
The Winnipeg Herald for a few years. I am not sure of the name. In Sunday school we received "Onward" and other Methodist publications.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. We kept these until they closed.

Publication and still I get The Christian Guardian which has become "The United Church Observer".

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

Many of the same but we moved several times and usually gave away all fiction and some others to S.S. library and friends on account of their weight.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. As for the above were weekly papers and also received S.S. papers, as Onward and others for the children.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? A violin, an organ, etc.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Many had violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Came here after 1914.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

We had occasional sing-a-long or practice, mostly hymns or sacred songs.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

chiefly the old songs as "Turkey in the Old Campground," "Way Down Upon the Western Side," "Out Where the West Begins," "O Give Me a Home Where the Buffalo Roam."

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

No folk music unless I'm going back to Dixieland and such old American folk songs.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
